title: Millionaire Tory Chancellor Philip Hammond refuses point-blank to publish his tax return
text:

Millionaire Tory Chancellor Philip Hammond has refused point-blank to publish his tax return. 
The MP snapped today when he was asked if he'd take the same move as his Labour rival to set an example ahead of the 2017 Budget. 
"I have no intention of doing so," he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show. 
"Just for the record my tax affairs are all perfectly regular and up to date. 
"But this demonstration politics isn’t helping to create a better atmosphere in British politics." Read More 
The call was made by Labour's Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell after he published his own tax return for 2015/15. Philip Hammond snapped: "This demonstration politics isn’t helping" (Photo: BBC) 
Mr McDonnell's return shows he paid income tax of £16,177 in 2015/16 on earnings of £66,943. He did not declare any earnings from a second job. 
Mr Hammond, who made his fortune via stakes in a nursing home developer and from consultancy work, is one of Parliament's richest MPs with a net worth estimated at £8.2million in 2014. 
This week the Shadow Chancellor revealed Labour would force people who earn £1million a year to publish their tax records public. 
Mr Hammond slammed the plan, saying: "That is likely to drive away talent and investors that Britain needs to create the global future we’re trying to build." 
British tax laws work under a strict principle of confidentiality between individual bill-payers and HM Revenue and Customs, making Mr McDonnell's idea a radical shake-up. 
In a round of TV interviews today, Mr Hammond also warned there would be no "spending spree" in his 2017 Budget on Wednesday. John McDonnell's return shows he paid income tax of £16,177 in 2015/16 
It's been revealed the Budget will give councils more than £1bn emergency cash for social care, £500m for skills training and a crackdown on misleading small print. 
But Mr Hammond said: "If someone gives you a bit more headroom on your credit card it doesn’t mean you need to rush out and spend it all at once." 
Mr Hammond also warned the EU that Britain will "fight back" and not "slink off like a wounded animal" if it does not get the Brexit deal it wants. 
In some of the toughest talking yet ahead of the UK triggering Article 50, the Chancellor said Britain would "do whatever we need to do" to be competitive in the event of leaving the EU without a trade agreement. 
Mr Hammond told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show: "If there is anybody in the European Union who thinks that if we don't do a deal with the European Union, if we don't continue to work closely together, Britain will simply slink off as a wounded animal, that is not going to happen. 
"British people have a great fighting spirit and we will fight back. We will forge new trade deals around the world. We will build our business globally." 
Asked if this meant the UK would slash business taxes to become a Singapore-style tax haven, he said: "People can read what they like into it. I'm not going to speculate now on how the UK would respond to what I don't expect to be the outcome." Theresa May is facing tense negotiations over an EU 'divorce bill' (Photo: REUTERS) 
Elsewhere Mr Hammond indicated Britain WOULD pay a 'divorce bill' ordered by the EU, telling ITV's Robert Peston: "If there are any outstanding dues we obliged to pay of course we will pay them. That’s the sort of country we are." 
But he dismissed claims of a 60billion Euros figure, saying: "This is positioning ahead of a negotiation and we should see it for exactly what it is." 
He said the pound's fall against the dollar would cause higher inflation. 
And he signalled he would be "dealing with the short-term disparities” which have left councils desperate for social care funding. 
"This isn’t a shift at all," he said. "Nobody is going to lose any benefit here." Read More 
And he failed to deny the Tories could face fresh by-elections amid a police investigation into how 2015 election expenses were declared. 
"The party has already acknowledged we made an administrative error," he said. 
"The due process has to be followed through and we will co operate fully with the Electoral Commission." Like us on Facebook
